sen.j: 楠木氏（くすのきし）は、河内国の豪族で、南北朝時代_(日本)に活躍した南朝 (日本)方の武家。
sen.e: The Kusunoki clan is a part of the Gozoku, a local ruling family of the Kawachi Province, and a samurai family of the Southern Court of Japan.
The Kusunoki clan was Gozoku, a local ruling family of the Kawachi Province, and a samurai family of the Southern Court of Japan.
sen.cmt: is→was a part of theを削除
sen.e: The Kusunoki clan was Gozoku, a local ruling family of the Kawachi Province, and a samurai family of the Southern Court of Japan.

sen.j: 「楠氏」と表記される事もある。
sen.e: Sometimes it is written 'Nanshi (楠氏).'
Sometimes it is written 'Nanshi (楠氏).'
Sometimes it is written 'Nanshi (楠氏).'

sen.j: 本姓は熊野国造の系統に属する伊予国の伊予橘氏（越智氏の分家）の橘遠保という。
sen.e: His real name is Tachibana no Toyasu and lived in the Iyo Province of the Iyotachibana clan that descended from Kumanokuni no miyatsuko.
sen.cmt: There seems to be some background information missing for this paragraph. I am not sure if the translation was done approprieately.
sen.e: His real name was Tachibana no Toyasu and he lived in the Iyo Province of the Iyotachibana clan (a branch family of the Ochi clan) that descended from Kumanokuni no miyatsuko.
His real name was Tachibana no Toyasu and he lived in the Iyo Province of the Iyotachibana clan (a branch family of the Ochi clan) that descended from Kumanokuni no miyatsuko.

sen.j: しかし、楠木正成以前の系図は諸家で一致せず、後世の創作と見られる。
sen.e: However, genealogies of the Kusunoki clan found in different families do not match before the the time of Masanari Kusunoki and are thought to have been made up by later generations.
However, genealogies of the Kusunoki clan found in different families do not match before the the time of Masashige KUSUNOKI and are thought to have been made up by later generations.
However, genealogies of the Kusunoki clan found in different families do not match before the the time of Masashige KUSUNOKI and are thought to have been made up by later generations.

sen.j: 確実なのは、河内の悪党の棟梁格だったことである（あるいは秦氏の系統との見方もある）。
sen.e: One thing that is certain is that they were Akuto (a villain in the medieval times) of the toryo (head of the clan) in Kawachi (or some view that they were descended from the Hata clan)
One thing that is certain is that they were the head of Akuto (a villain in the medieval times) in Kawachi (or some view that they were descended from the Hata clan)
One thing that is certain is that they were the head of Akuto (a villain in the medieval times) in Kawachi (or some view that they were descended from the Hata clan)

sen.j: 戦後、名和長年と同じく辰砂の採掘権と技術を有した商人的武装集団の頭目説、散所の長者説などが出されたが、いまだ定説は存在しない。
sen.e: After the World War II, there were several theories as to the family origins such as the Kusunoki being the chief of an armed group of merchants who possessed the rights and skills of exploitation, for example, like Nagatoshi Nawa, or billionares in sanjo (manor's area where people of the sanjo provided special skills to the imperial authority instead of rice tax); to date, none of these theories have been proven.

After the World War II, there were several theories as to the family origins such as the Kusunoki being the chief of an armed group of merchants who possessed the rights and skills of cinnabar exploitation, for example, like Nagatoshi NAWA, or billionares in sanjo (manor's area where people of the sanjo provided special skills to the imperial authority instead of rice tax); to date, none of these theories have been proven.

After the World War II, there were several theories as to the family origins such as the Kusunoki being the chief of an armed group of merchants who possessed the rights and skills of cinnabar exploitation, for example, like Nagatoshi NAWA, or billionares in sanjo (manor's area where people of the sanjo provided special skills to the imperial authority instead of rice tax); to date, none of these theories have been proven.

sen.j: また、河内国の金剛山観心寺領の在地豪族ともされるが、河内国や近隣には「楠木」という苗字の元となる地名はない。
sen.e: It is also viewed that they were the local powerful clan in the territories of the Kanshin-ji Temple of Kongo-san Mountain in Kawachi Province; however, place names that trace back their origins to the family name 'Kusuniki' has not been found in the Kawachi Province or its surrounding neighbourhoods.

It is also viewed that they were the local powerful clan in the territories of the Kanshin-ji Temple of Kongo-san Mountain in Kawachi Province; however, place names that trace back their origins to the family name 'Kusuniki' has not been found in the Kawachi Province or its surrounding neighbourhoods.

It is also viewed that they were the local powerful clan in the territories of the Kanshin-ji Temple of Kongo-san Mountain in Kawachi Province; however, place names that trace back their origins to the family name 'Kusuniki' has not been found in the Kawachi Province or its surrounding neighbourhoods.

sen.j: 近年では『吾妻鏡』によると、元は関東にいた御家人で、玉井氏・忍氏・岡部氏・滝瀬氏ら武蔵七党の横山党や猪俣党と並ぶ家柄であり、もともとは利根川流域に基盤をもつ東国武士の有力集団の一派だったという。
sen.e: Recently, it has been noted that the record on "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East) states that originally they were one of the powerful samurai groups in the eastern part of Japan, Togoku Samurai, who were based in the area of Tonegawa River and also gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods)who belonged to an upper class like Tamai, Okabe, and Takise of the Musashi-shichito Parties (seven parties of samurai in Musashi Province) or the Inomata Party.

Recently, it has been noted that the record on "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East) states that originally they were one of the powerful samurai groups in the eastern part of Japan, Togoku Samurai, who were based in the area of Tonegawa River and also gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods)who belonged to an upper class like Tamai clan, Okabe clan, Nin clan and Takise clan from the Musashi-shichito Parties such as Yokoyama Party or Inomata Party (seven parties of samurai in Musashi Province).
sen.cmt: 括弧の位置を移動訳抜けを修正原文に合わせて修正
sen.e: Recently, it has been noted that the record on "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East) states that originally they were one of the powerful samurai groups in the eastern part of Japan, Togoku Samurai, who were based in the area of Tonegawa River and also gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods)who belonged to an upper class like Tamai clan, Okabe clan, Nin clan and Takise clan from the Musashi-shichito Parties such as Yokoyama Party or Inomata Party (seven parties of samurai in Musashi Province).

sen.j: 実際にその東国武家集団は北条得宗家の被官として、赤松氏と共に播磨や摂津・南河内・和泉など北条氏の守護国などに得宗領に移住した事項があるので、そのまま、土着したのではないかと言われている。
sen.e: As the matter of fact, it has been recorded that as the hikan, a low-level bureaucrat, of the Tokuso Family of the Hojo clan, Togoku Samurai moved to their Shugo's territory, such as Harima, Minamikawachi, and Izumi, it is thought that they may have settled down in these areas.

It has been recorded that as the hikan (a low-level bureaucrat) of the Tokuso Family of the Hojo clan, Togoku Samurai in fact moved to their Shugo's territory, such as Harima, Minamikawachi, and Izumi, it is thought that they may have settled down in these areas.
sen.cmt: コンマの代わりに括弧As the matter of fact→In fact
sen.e: It has been recorded that as the hikan (a low-level bureaucrat) of the Tokuso Family of the Hojo clan, Togoku Samurai in fact moved to their Shugo's territory, such as Harima, Minamikawachi, and Izumi, it is thought that they may have settled down in these areas.

sen.j: 史料上はっきり記されているのは、鎌倉時代後期に楠木正成が後醍醐天皇が鎌倉幕府に対して挙兵した元弘の乱において宮方に従い、幕府滅亡後に成立した建武政権に加わり、南北朝時代 (日本)に南朝 (日本)（吉野朝廷）方として活躍した以降である。
sen.e: What is clear from the historical record is that MK fought together with the court during the Genko war when Emperor Godaigo raised an army against Kamakura bakufu, who were Japanese feudal lords under the shogun, and joined the Kenmy Government established after the fall of the bakufu and prospered as the Souther Court, or Yoshino Court, during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

What is clear from the historical records is that Masashige KUSUNOKI fought together with the court during the Genko War when Emperor Godaigo raised an army against the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), joined the Kenmu Government established after the fall of the bakufu, and played an active role on the side of the Southern Court, or Yoshino Court, during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.
sen.cmt: MK→Masashige KUSUNOKIwar→Warbakufu の補足説明を修正 スペル修正 Kenmy→Kenmu
sen.e: What is clear from the historical records is that Masashige KUSUNOKI fought together with the court during the Genko War when Emperor Godaigo raised an army against the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), joined the Kenmu Government established after the fall of the bakufu, and played an active role on the side of the Southern Court, or Yoshino Court, during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

sen.j: その後正成の子の楠木正行、楠木正時や、正成の弟の楠木正季などは北朝 (日本)の足利尊氏との戦いで戦死し、生き残った正成の子の楠木正儀は南朝零落後にも有力武将として活躍し、北朝との和睦を仲介する。
sen.e: After that, Masanari's sons, Masatsura KUSUNOKI and Masatoki KUSUNOKI, and younger brother, Masasue KUSUNOKI, died in battle with Takauji ASHIKAGA; however, another son of Masanari, Masanori KUSUNOKI, survived even after the Southern Court's fall into straitened circumstances and served actively as a powerful military commander and served as a mediator of the reconciliation with the Northern Court.

After that, Masashige's sons, Masatsura KUSUNOKI and Masatoki KUSUNOKI, and younger brother, Masasue KUSUNOKI, died in battle with Takauji ASHIKAGA of the Northern court; however, another son of Masashige, Masanori KUSUNOKI, survived even after the Southern Court's fall into straitened circumstances and served actively as a powerful military commander and served as a mediator of the reconciliation with the Northern Court.

After that, Masashige's sons, Masatsura KUSUNOKI and Masatoki KUSUNOKI, and younger brother, Masasue KUSUNOKI, died in battle with Takauji ASHIKAGA of the Northern court; however, another son of Masashige, Masanori KUSUNOKI, survived even after the Southern Court's fall into straitened circumstances and served actively as a powerful military commander and served as a mediator of the reconciliation with the Northern Court.

sen.j: その後、正儀の子孫は播磨国で平木氏を名乗ったとも言われている。
sen.e: It is also said that the descendants of Masanori later used 'Hiraki' as their clan name in the Harima Province.
It is also said that the descendants of Masanori later used 'Hiraki' as their clan name in the Harima Province.
It is also said that the descendants of Masanori later used 'Hiraki' as their clan name in the Harima Province.

sen.j: なお、昭和37年（1962年）、三重県上野市（現・伊賀市）の旧家から発見された上嶋家文書（江戸時代末期の写本）によると、伊賀、服部氏族の上嶋元成の三男が猿楽（能）の大成者である観阿弥で、その母は楠木正成の姉妹であるという。
sen.e: According to the kamijima-ke bunsho (documents of the Kamijima family; it was the manuscript from the end of Edo Period) found in 1962 from an old house in Ueno city (present day Iga city) in Mie Prefecture, the third son of Gensei UESHIMA is the master of sarugaku (form of theatre popular in Japan during the 11th to 14th centuries) or Noh, Kanami, and his mother is a sister of Masanari.

According to the kamijima-ke bunsho (documents of the Kamijima family; it was the manuscript from the end of Edo Period) found in 1962 from an old house in Ueno city (present day Iga city) in Mie Prefecture, the third son of Gensei UESHIMA is Kanami, the master of sarugaku (form of theatre popular in Japan during the 11th to 14th centuries) or Noh and his mother is a sister of Masashige.

According to the kamijima-ke bunsho (documents of the Kamijima family; it was the manuscript from the end of Edo Period) found in 1962 from an old house in Ueno city (present day Iga city) in Mie Prefecture, the third son of Gensei UESHIMA is Kanami, the master of sarugaku (form of theatre popular in Japan during the 11th to 14th centuries) or Noh and his mother is a sister of Masashige.

sen.j: 上嶋家文書の真偽をめぐって学界では意見がわかれ、概ね否定的見解が主流であったが、後にその記載内容を裏書きする古文書が兵庫県揖保郡揖保川町新在家の豪農であった永富家（元楠木同族会顧問 鹿島建設株式会社会長鹿島守之助の生家）から発見され、この系図は江戸後期の写しであっても、古本を書写したものであることが証明された。
sen.e: The credibility of this document has been a controversial issue in the society of Japanese history that majority of them viewed as false; however, an old documents that was found in the house of a waelthy farmer, the Nagatomi family in Shinzaike, Ibokawa-cho in Ibo-gun, Hyogo Prefecture and it was revealed that this geneology recorded in this manuscrit during the late Edo Period was actually copied from an old document.

The credibility of this document has been a controversial issue in the society of Japanese history that majority of them viewed as false; however, an old document that was found in the house of a wealthy farmer, the Nagatomi family (the birthplace of Morinosuke KAJIMA who was the chairman of Kajima Corporation and the former advisor of the Kusunoki family council) in Shinzaike, Ibokawa-cho in Ibo-gun, Hyogo Prefecture and it was revealed that this geneology recorded in this manuscrit during the late Edo Period was actually copied from an old document.
sen.cmt: documents→documentスペルミス修正 waelthy→wealthy訳抜け補足
sen.e: The credibility of this document has been a controversial issue in the society of Japanese history that majority of them viewed as false; however, an old document that was found in the house of a wealthy farmer, the Nagatomi family (the birthplace of Morinosuke KAJIMA who was the chairman of Kajima Corporation and the former advisor of the Kusunoki family council) in Shinzaike, Ibokawa-cho in Ibo-gun, Hyogo Prefecture and it was revealed that this geneology recorded in this manuscrit during the late Edo Period was actually copied from an old document.

tit.e: After the unification of Southern and Northern Courts
After the unification of Southern and Northern Courts
After the unification of Southern and Northern Courts

sen.j: 楠木氏の一族は殆どが南朝方についた。
sen.e: Most familes from the Kusunoki clan took sides with the Souther Court.
Most familes from the Kusunoki clan took sides with the Southern Court.
Most familes from the Kusunoki clan took sides with the Southern Court.

sen.j: そのため、南朝の凋落と共に一族も没落した。
sen.e: Therefore, when the Southern court fell so did the Kusunoki clan.
Therefore, when the Southern court fell so did the families.
Therefore, when the Southern court fell so did the families.

sen.j: 南北朝合一後に後南朝の武将としても楠木正秀や楠木光正ら楠木氏一族が確認できる。
sen.e: Even after the unification of the Courts, Kusunoki families continued to be active, producing some of the notable figures such as Masahide KUSUNIKI and Mitsumasa KUSUNOKI, who served as military commanders.

Even after the unification of the Courts, Kusunoki families continued to be active, producing some of the notable figures such as Masahide KUSUNIKI and Mitsumasa KUSUNOKI, who served as military commanders of Gonancho (Second Southern Court).
sen.cmt: 訳抜けを補足→Gonancho (Second Southern Court)
sen.e: Even after the unification of the Courts, Kusunoki families continued to be active, producing some of the notable figures such as Masahide KUSUNIKI and Mitsumasa KUSUNOKI, who served as military commanders of Gonancho (Second Southern Court).

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には楠木正成の末裔と自称する楠木正虎なる人物が現れ、北朝を擁立した足利幕府の時代に朝廷（北朝）に仇をなしたとして逆賊扱いであった楠木氏の名誉回復のために、朝廷や織田信長に援助を求めて名誉回復に尽力した。
sen.e: During the Sengoku period (period of warring states), Masatora KUSUNOKI, who calls himself as the descendant of Masanari KUSUNOKI appeared and made efforts on restoring impaired reputation of the Kusunoki clan, who he thought was treated as gyakuzoku (rebel) by the Imperial court as having done them an ill office by backing up the Northern Court during the era of Ashikaga Shogunate, seeking assistance from Imperial court and Nobunaga ODA.

During the Sengoku period (period of warring states), Masatora KUSUNOKI, who calls himself as the descendant of Masashige KUSUNOKI appeared and made efforts on restoring impaired reputation of the Kusunoki clan, who he thought was treated as gyakuzoku (rebel) by the Imperial court as having done them an ill office during the era of Ashikaga Shogunate that backed up the Northern Court, seeking assistance from Imperial court and Nobunaga ODA.
sen.cmt: Masanari→Masashigeスペース調整原文に合わせて修正
sen.e: During the Sengoku period (period of warring states), Masatora KUSUNOKI, who calls himself as the descendant of Masashige KUSUNOKI appeared and made efforts on restoring impaired reputation of the Kusunoki clan, who he thought was treated as gyakuzoku (rebel) by the Imperial court as having done them an ill office during the era of Ashikaga Shogunate that backed up the Northern Court, seeking assistance from Imperial court and Nobunaga ODA.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、慶安の変を起こした由井正雪が正虎の子という楠木正辰（楠木不伝）に軍学を学び、正辰の娘婿となった。
sen.e: During the Edo period, Shosetsu YUI, who was the catalyst of Keian Incident, learned military science from Masatora (or Fuden) KUSUNOKI and became the husband of his daughter.
During the Edo period, Shosetsu YUI, who was the catalyst of Keian Incident, learned military science from Masatatsu (or Fuden) KUSUNOKI and became the husband of his daughter.
During the Edo period, Shosetsu YUI, who was the catalyst of Keian Incident, learned military science from Masatatsu (or Fuden) KUSUNOKI and became the husband of his daughter.

sen.j: 南朝が正統な朝廷とする史観が定着するや、楠木正成や楠木氏は忠臣の代表として賞賛され、顕彰されるようになる。
sen.e: From the time when the Southern Court became well recogized as the orthodox Imperial court, Masanari KUSUNOKI and the Kusunoki clan were priased as the representative of loyal subjects and were even rewarded.

From the time when the Southern Court became well recogized as the orthodox Imperial court, Masashige KUSUNOKI and the Kusunoki clan were praised as the representative of loyal subjects and were even rewarded.

From the time when the Southern Court became well recogized as the orthodox Imperial court, Masashige KUSUNOKI and the Kusunoki clan were praised as the representative of loyal subjects and were even rewarded.

sen.j: しかし、明治政府の国家権力を以てしても、楠木氏末裔を称する氏族は数多いものの、楠木氏の直系の子孫を確認する事はできなかった。
sen.e: Even though there were many families who identified as the descendants of the Kusuniki clan, the direct desdant has not been confirmed yet.
sen.cmt: As it was hard to understand the meaning of the following part, it is not translated: 明治政府の国家権力を以てして
sen.e: Although there were many families who were identified as being descendants of the Kusuniki clan, it was not possible to confirm whether they were direct descendants, even when the state power of the Meiji government was used.

Although there were many families who were identified as being descendants of the Kusuniki clan, it was not possible to confirm whether they were direct descendants, even when the state power of the Meiji government was used.

sen.j: そのため、同じ南朝の忠臣でも、菊池氏や名和氏などは子孫が華族に列したが、楠木氏からは華族は生まれていない。
sen.e: Therefore, although other loyal families of the Southern Court such as the Kikuchi clan and the Nagayasu clan were raised to the peerage, there has been no peerage from the Kusuniki clan.
Therefore, although other loyal families of the Southern Court such as the Kikuchi clan and the Nawa clan were raised to the peerage, there has been no peerage from the Kusuniki clan.
Therefore, although other loyal families of the Southern Court such as the Kikuchi clan and the Nawa clan were raised to the peerage, there has been no peerage from the Kusuniki clan.

sen.j: 明治末から昭和初期の作詞家野口雨情の先祖は、正成の弟にあたる楠木正季であるという。
sen.e: It is said that the song writer Ujo NOGUCHI, who was active between the end of Meiji Period and Showa Period, is the descendant of Masaki KUSUNOKI and the younger brother of Masanari KUSUNIKI.

It is said that the song writer Ujo NOGUCHI, who was active between the end of Meiji Period and the early Showa Period, is the descendant of Masaki KUSUNOKI and the younger brother of Masashige KUSUNOKI.
sen.cmt: the early を追加Masanari→Masashigeスペルミス修正 KUSUNIKI→KUSUNOKI
sen.e: It is said that the song writer Ujo NOGUCHI, who was active between the end of Meiji Period and the early Showa Period, is the descendant of Masaki KUSUNOKI and the younger brother of Masashige KUSUNOKI.

sen.j: また、地理学者・地球物理学で南極地域観測隊を3次にわたって務めた楠宏は楠木正成の子孫にあたるという。
sen.e: It is also said that Ko KUSUNOKI, a geologist and geophysist who served three times as the Japanese Antarctic Research Expedition (JARE) is the descendant of Masanari KUSUNOKI.
It is also said that Ko KUSUNOKI, a geologist and geophysist who served three times as the Japanese Antarctic Research Expedition (JARE) is the descendant of Masashige KUSUNOKI.
It is also said that Ko KUSUNOKI, a geologist and geophysist who served three times as the Japanese Antarctic Research Expedition (JARE) is the descendant of Masashige KUSUNOKI.

sen.j: その後、1935年（昭和10年）の大楠公600年祭時に、ついに確認された楠木氏子孫によって、湊川神社内に楠木同族会が結成されて現在に至っている。
sen.e: Later, the Kusunoki family council was formed in the Minatogawa-jinja Shrine by the those who were finally confirmed as the descendants of the Kusunoki clan during the Dai-Nanko 600 years anniversary held in 1935 and is still active today.

Later, the Kusunoki family council was formed in the Minatogawa-jinja Shrine by the those who were finally confirmed as the descendants of the Kusunoki clan during the Dai-Nanko 600 years anniversary held in 1935 and is still active today.

Later, the Kusunoki family council was formed in the Minatogawa-jinja Shrine by the those who were finally confirmed as the descendants of the Kusunoki clan during the Dai-Nanko 600 years anniversary held in 1935 and is still active today.
